data.source: State-level datasets (panel data) including carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion, working hours, GDP-related measures, employment, demographics; includes League of Conservation Voters’ scores (1990–2005) for state environmentalism
data.notes: Balanced panel; continuous variables logged; Prais–Winsten models with panel-corrected standard errors (PCSEs) and AR(1) within panels; includes census region dummies; hybrid models used for robustness.

method.description: The study uses panel regression models on a balanced panel of U.S. states (2007–2013) to estimate the relationship between average weekly working hours and state-level CO2 emissions, assessing both scale and composition effects while controlling for political, economic, and demographic factors.
steps: Assemble a balanced panel dataset for all 50 states for 2007–2013, including CO2 emissions, average weekly working hours, GDP-related measures, employment ratios, demographics, energy production, manufacturing share, and state environmentalism (LCV scores).
Specify two-way fixed-effects and random-effects panel models to estimate scale and composition effects.
Estimate Prais–Winsten regressions with AR(1) correction and panel-corrected standard errors.
Include census region dummies and state environmentalism controls; use hybrid models for robustness checks.
Assess statistical significance and interpret elasticities for working hours on CO2 emissions.
method.models: Two-way fixed-effects and random-effects panel regressions; Prais–Winsten with AR(1) and panel-corrected standard errors; hybrid models for robustness; logged specifications.
method.outcome_variable: State-level carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion (logged)
method.independent_variables: Average weekly working hours per worker (logged). For scale models: working hours, labor productivity (GDP per hour), employment-to-population ratio. For composition models: working hours net of GDP (e.g., including GDP per capita).
method.control_variables: Total population size; state energy production; manufacturing as a percentage of GDP; household size; working-age ratio; census region dummy variables; state environmentalism (League of Conservation Voters scores).

results.summary: Longer average working hours are associated with higher state-level CO2 emissions. Both scale and composition effects are statistically significant, indicating that increases in working hours raise emissions even when accounting for GDP and other controls. Population and energy production increase emissions, while stronger state environmentalism relates to lower emissions. Findings suggest working-time reduction could help reduce emissions.
